[16.11.24, 18:10:51] ~â€¯Robert: It's expensive af. The pros are you don't have to handle shipping. The cons are you will pay a lot for sales, usually around $1 per item. [18.11.24, 3:01:21] Bob: Mainly onlinejobs for us. We give them a very short trial task where they basically just create a lead to keep the barrier of creating this low as it is a free test.

[22.11.24, 17:35:31] ~â€¯Igor: Few years ago worked as affiliate with CoD offers in post Soviet countries. So yes, as Buzeed said - call center is a must with strong scripts. They do pre shipment calls and follow ups calls if package is not received(usually package is awaiting at courier service pick up points) 
Depends on your case - if your package is based at pick up points- follow up calls with potential discount is a solution, if you ship CoD directly to customer - then pre shipment + pre arrival call should be a solution.
[22.11.24, 17:39:41] ~â€¯Bazeed: yeah u cant unfortunately completely get rid of rto but u can test offers as well where you incentivise towards using prepayment for additional 10% off, etc

and the higher your repeat rate is the lower the RTO goes and that means u gotta be branding well
[22.11.24, 17:52:00] ~â€¯Timotej: Regarding COD â€¦

By far the most important things to reduce rejection-rate:

1. shipping time - each day the customer waits longer, % of rejections increases
2. â SMS sequence - be aggressive and send out daily 
3. â carrier optimizationâ€¦ different EU markets, sometimes means different carriers

[25.11.24, 13:21:14] ~â€¯Growg: The best way to do is to reverse engineer the things- 

1. Co-relate the pain you are solving with other niche. See how they have successfully solved
Ex- If you are solving say Anti agrning cream so similar niche in Co-morbidity is solving to minimise the risk of it not get anti aging. 

Goal - Is to find and connect pain point you are solving is solved by other niche for you Avatar or not. 

2. Clearly define Avatar day to day routine and how your product will make theri pain solve/improve. Call at least 100 people and jot down what you got similarities. 

3. Start with $50-$100 after you have contacted the 100 people and had drawn specificity. 

Hope this helps.

[1.12.24, 4:13:58] ~â€¯Igor: For subscriptions I can recommend to stick to Shopify Payments as per my experience. They have free app(Shopify Subscriptions) and ready integration. Easy native contract management. 

The thing is 3rd party subscription providers do not render subscription elements in checkout ( at least per my experience with Cybersource) and these elements like recurring total, recurring shipping and deffered payment notice are legally required to be present in Checkout here in EU(Austria). 

Check if your subscription provider render these elements in checkout and if this is legal requirement in the country you operate.

Upd: I see that seal natively integrates with Shopify contracts and checkout looks goodğŸ‘ â€<This message was edited>

[2.12.24, 0:41:00] ~â€¯N: Quick way to get 10 new ad scripts and find your next winning ad that scales with AI 

#1. Take your winning ad script and upload it to claude.

"Here is my winning ad script. Please take a second to analyze and familiarize yourself with the product. Once you're done, let me know."

#2. Tell claude to analyze your last 10 losing ad scripts.

"Now here is the last 10 scripts we've tested that have all lost and did not make us money. Please take a second to analyze them."

#3. Ask claude to help you on new angles based off this data.

"Now that you've gotten to analyze both winning and losing, please give me a list of things i'm not touching on that could improve performance OR a list of angles that I have not tried yet that would likely be a winner"

#4. Ask claude to write you a hook for each

"Please write me a hook for each one, i could then turn into an ad"

#5. Write an ad script for each

"Please write me an ad script for each"

#6. Double space & add b-roll

"Please double space each sentence and add b-roll for each sentence"

#7. Copy to a google doc

#8. Send to top performing content creator you use

#9. Launch new video content

[15.12.24, 7:00:09] ~â€¯Mithiran: Are you talking about one campaign structure?
[15.12.24, 7:03:38] ~â€¯Mithiran: We tried multiple testing campaigns, every single one of them flopped and wasted a shit ton of money. [15.12.24, 7:06:48] ~â€¯Dr Zied: How many adsets? And broad or interest targeting?

[15.12.24, 12:11:30] ~â€¯Nick Jansen: I launch new CBO campaigns with holiday-specific themes, like Christmas and Black Friday, to ensure my all-time winning ads in the original CBO remain unaffected by the sales of limited-time offers. For example, during Black Friday, I slightly downscale the evergreen campaigns to prioritize the holiday deals while keeping their performance steady.
[15.12.24, 12:13:37] ~â€¯Bazeed: interesting and with the holiday specific cbo, what difference do you make
[15.12.24, 12:13:41] ~â€¯Bazeed: do you change the landing page?
[15.12.24, 12:13:56] ~â€¯Bazeed: because im assuming you cant change the copy or  headlines in the ad itself if youre using post id
[15.12.24, 12:19:10] ~â€¯Nick Jansen: Exactly! For holiday offers, we essentially iterate on our winning campaigns to align with the upcoming holiday. Since we run a 1+1 free offer year-round, thereâ€™s no need for major changes to the landing page. We simply make minor tweaks to the ads, such as updating the scripts, scroll-stoppers, and calls-to-action, and then launch them into a new holiday-themed CBO. ğŸ˜„

Usually sundays are amazing for us but we had a really bad sunday yesterday compared to our usual days, but that is ads.

Ads are up and down, is what it is, maximize ur cvr, aov, etc, do all that is within your control ğŸ‘
[30.12.24, 14:13:56] ~â€¯Klemen: Thanks ğŸ™ Do you downscale the budget or just pause the campaign? 
I tried scaling down but when i decrease the budget the campaign still overspends, in most cases still 80% of the budget before downscale
[30.12.24, 17:00:58] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: @â¨~Nikola Petkovâ© - I could definitely give you input on optimizing it. DM me when you have time.
[30.12.24, 17:04:53] ~â€¯Caesar: No I never pause the campaign, a day without running ads is a day lost in my eyes. 

I just downscale the budget.

The reason it still spends is because you downscale during the day.

Budget downscaling on Meta has to be done at midnight, if u do it during the day it wont make a difference from what I see, it will still spend until the OG budget you had.

That is why i always analyze my ads at midnight (well, our media buyer does but you get the point).

If unprofitable i scale down by at least half, usually that fixes it until i find sweet spot, and i just stay there.

Not all products can scale, not all ads can scale.
[30.12.24, 17:05:59] ~â€¯Caesar: And yes, this is why downscaling during the day isnt even an option really, you can scale up during the day though "surf-scaling", but that's if you are proitable and with a good ROAS to merit that kind of agressive scaling, you may have had a good morning, but the evening is coming, the dark times... demons come out at the night time usually bro

[2.01.25, 7:42:34] ~â€¯Robert: It's hard to advertise without an insane offer. The offer is like your bread and butter. Figuring out what they want as an offer is also complex, it shouldn't be as simple as BOGO or B1G1 50% off.. It should be something they actually buy. You should be able to analyze your sales data and see what they would like as a bundle.

At the end of the day. Facebook ads aren't a way to make one sale and profit from that one sale. Facebook ads are a way to introduce people to your brand. Understand your LTV:CAC pull them in and cash out on future cash flow through email campaigns/flows. Your offer is what secures your future cash flow.
[2.01.25, 7:43:34] ~â€¯Robert: Other people may disagree but that's how I view advertising on facebook.

[6.01.25, 7:56:22] ~â€¯Brian: It depends on what kind of test you are doing.

If you know you have a winning script (copy) hook, then you can iterate on different visual hooks.

If you know a visual hook works well, you can test new script (copy) hooks with that visual.

If your ad is doing OK consistently near BE ROAS and you believe the hook can be improved, then you can do a visual & script (copy) hook change for the biggest impact.


Visual + Script (copy) hook change = biggest impact in performance

Visual hook change is usually second & Copy hook change only is third.
[6.01.25, 7:56:51] ~â€¯Brian: When I say script hook I just mean the copy of the hook. Using your terminology here
[6.01.25, 12:57:36] ~â€¯Mark: The way that I see it there are three elements to the hook: the copy itself (script), the video (scroll stopper), and the audio. All three of these should be split tested but their importance also follows that order. Script being the most important, video being the second most important, and audio being the third most important.

[15.01.25, 21:58:50] ~â€¯Denis Mihin: Big misconception is that you have 0% tax but thats not true most of the time.

If you are not a resident in countries like Dubai, Cayman Islands, Monaco. You pay tax in your local country!

You are subject to worldwide income. Almost all europe countries tax you on your global income.

So if you have a US LLC you only have 0% tax in US, but you pay tax in your country of residence.

[16.01.25, 6:35:32] ~â€¯Carlos: People have to understand that Wyoming/Delaware/Hong Kong LLCs are a great tool to have in this space but they are not a get out of jail free card.

By all means use them, but everyone has to be aware that without moving residency, those LLCs aren't a magical cloak of protection from your local tax authority.

Any european country will simply say that there's no substance in that company and that as a resident you have to claim the entirety of the income of that LLC as your personal income in your taxes. From a legal standpoint, most tax codes consider that those companies don't exist if you have nothing that shows that they serve any purpose other than tax evasion.

So yeah go ahead and use them but be aware of the risk. You're still operating in grey areas and hoping to not get caught.

Once you hit it big what makes sense is to either accept the real tax bill in your country or move residency to a 0% or low income tax country (UAE, Cyprus, Andorra). â€<This message was edited>

[16.01.25, 20:27:05] ~â€¯Mithiran: We use the main CBO method and i dont really touch minimum spend. [25.01.25, 22:12:36] ~â€¯Austin: Has anyone here trained or hired a media buyer for their account? Would love to know how that went.
[25.01.25, 22:18:11] Topi: - want to hire someone with experience spending more than youâ€™re currently spending. 

- Must be obsessed, media buying is 7 days a week job

- Want to tie in profit based comission. Prefetably higher comission/ lower retainer contract 

- Want to ask proof of success previously and prefetablly reach out to previous company (fake screenshots etc) 

- Want to hire person who understands sales funnel as holistic level, not a person who presses buttons only 

- Fast trial, cannot get things working? Find new one


These are few my learnings about media buyers so far
[25.01.25, 22:20:29] ~â€¯Austin: Very helpful thank you

[26.01.25, 0:04:44] ~â€¯Santi Roa: Both ways are correct. It's just a strategy decision
[26.01.25, 0:06:38] ~â€¯Lucas Alves: exactly
[26.01.25, 0:08:24] ~â€¯Steve: I see your point but experience has taught me this is not the sustainable approach.

The reason is because you really have to have an excellent nose to sniff out great talent early and invest in growing those ones. Most people don't have that so they invest time and money investing In someone who will not become an A player.

The other drawback is you take a D player and turn them into an A player. Awesome. But now they have become an A player for the first time in their career meaning the can go work wherever the want for whatever money they want. And they often (not always) choose to leave
[26.01.25, 0:09:14] ~â€¯Steve: Where hiring an A player, yes it's expensive, but they are already coming to you by choice, and expected to do an A level job which accelerates your business to the maximum making them a high ROI hire that you don't have to invest training dollars in
[26.01.25, 0:09:51] ~â€¯Santi Roa: I my case I consciously make the decision to build a great culture, a very positive work environment, and having a strong recruiting funnel and process.
Then, with that, I am able to hire top talent, with a bit less specific experience than needed, but the capabilities to execute and improve fast. I keep investing in them, and people don't leave
[26.01.25, 0:10:04] ~â€¯Steve: You will inevitably have people in your business that you train up and should but you need to consider the time and cost of that training and the cost of the mistakes they make along the way vs just hiring a fucking killer to come in and kill
[26.01.25, 0:12:40] ~â€¯Steve: In the end it depends on position too. I'm not interested in hiring a Jr media buyer and then spending months training them up. I want an experienced person who knows what they're doing, and I'm happy to compensate them and keep bumping their comp and structure every 3 months or so to keep them happy
[26.01.25, 0:13:57] Topi: The positive side of hiring junior and coaching = extreme loyalty (my experience) 

Downside = the times Iâ€™ve tried to do this intentionally, at some point it went wrong and now as Iâ€™m getting more matured, I see the opportunity cost that this causes. 

The times a junior became senior, it happened naturally over time almost by accident. Right person + they had time to grow, that part of business wasnâ€™t causing bottleneck while they were growing

[27.01.25, 5:51:43] ~â€¯Mark Wagner: You should test this but it's normally in the range of 15-20% false positive rate on Ethoca alerts specifically. I run Disputifier and there are issues with false positives on virtually every other alert provider because of the way Ethoca works. Basically Ethoca inflates their alert count / revenue by sending "suspected fraud" notifications through as normal alerts. All other providers just send it as a chargeback notification and bill you for it. We filter these out because they're mostly bullshit and not actually going to turn into a chargeback
[27.01.25, 6:16:42] ~â€¯Charles: What do you guys think about the tariffs? For China Trump was talking maybe 10%

[1.02.25, 15:43:36] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: Yea. The 10% is really going to be nothing.  Plus if anyone in e-commerce is using this DDP method for shipping, which means you get a tracking number from FedEx or UPS, ur barely seeing a difference in price. 

For legitimate importing, the ten percent is most likely being added to the existing tariff categories.  There are categories that are tariff exempt, and then categories where you pay only 7.5%, 15%, and of course 25%.  So if itâ€™s 10% on top of everything, not the end of the world. If itâ€™s 10% on top of only the 25% category, thatâ€™s even better.  

If ur fulfilling from China, then youâ€™re not even impacted because of the de minimus rule. That can still change, but again itâ€™s not ruining your day.  There are things you can work out with the manufacturer to reduce your price anyway.
[1.02.25, 17:52:07] ~â€¯Mithiran: Wouldnâ€™t the 10% be added onto the DDP price
[1.02.25, 17:53:44] ~â€¯Zvi: hey all started a new product in france getting mixed results each day could it be becouse i selected on the ads set up advantage + audiences VS just leaving it Broad without that setting ?
[1.02.25, 18:01:50] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: no it doesnâ€™t really work that way, especially because of the way they price things out. They are charging per KG and its the shipping cost + taxes. Theyâ€™re definitely under declaring the value of the goods too, which is why DDP rates are so much cheaper than doing legitimate shipping where you have your own customs broker importing the products for you and youâ€™re receiving a customs enry form. 

The DDP service is basically a Chinese shipping service that is collecting as many different shipments and throwing it onto a container. Then when they handle the customs clearance, they are taking full responsibility of the importing, under declaring so that they are paying less in taxes. Then it goes to a warehouse, usually in LA, where all orders in the container gets separated and then scheduled for pickup by a UPS truck or Fedex track. That is why youâ€™ll see no movement in your shipment until it actually gets picked up in LA. 

When youâ€™re doing more legitimate sea freight shipping, theres a lot more to it. You have the sea freight cost, customs clearance cost, freight release cost, the actual duties/taxes ur paying (thatâ€™s when you have to provide a commercial invoice and packing list to your customs broker), and then trucking costs to the 3PL its going. For this type of shipping, youâ€™re able to track the whole process. You can track the vessel that youâ€™re shipment is on, youâ€™re getting updates from your customs broker about the customs clearance process, and youâ€™re getting true updates about the delivery schedules once the shipment is dispatched from customs. 

I have a client that we source machinery for them. They manufacture chocolate and candy nuts in the US. Let me share with you what a customs entry form looks like where you actually are paying the tariffs. They gave me approval to share it. One second.
â€[1.02.25, 18:03:25] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: kanary003 egsu.eisu.magu- 7501.pdf â€¢ â€2 pages â€document omitted
[1.02.25, 18:06:09] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: You can see here for this shipment that the tariff code for these chocolate machines are a 7.5% tariff. So assuming that Trump is slapping 10% on everything, it would be 17.5% now. Most of the consumer products that ecommerce businesses are selling fall under the 25% tariff category, which means that it would now be 35%. 

Again, DDP prices will increase most likely, but I donâ€™t think it will simply be a 10% increase. It may be with some providers, but these shipping companies doing DDP know they need to be as competitive as possible so that they donâ€™t lose market share from other providers.
[1.02.25, 18:08:00] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: Lastly, youâ€™ll notice in that document I sent above is an entry for machine parts. That particular HTS category falls under the 25% tariff. So asssuming Trump adds 10% to everything, then it would become 35%.
[1.02.25, 18:09:51] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: I do source for an ecommerce brand in the stationary product industry and some of his products are tariff exempt, which means he only pays duties, but no tariff. Iâ€™m curious if the tariff exempt categories will be affected by this additional 10% tariff. 

Hope this gives everyone a little bit more clarity on this whole trump tariff thing.

â€[5.02.25, 20:05:47] ~â€¯Ben Mansour: â€image omitted
[5.02.25, 20:21:41] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: I know a lot of people are nervous about the tariffs and how the removal of de minimis rule will affect supply chain. I posted on X to provide some clarification in case itâ€™s helpful to you or others you know: https://x.com/glepkoff127/status/1887170991291564137?s=48&t=dIcCk85uTvVXJZ0UzFLdXQ
[5.02.25, 20:28:47] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: Iâ€™ll update more as information becomes available.
[5.02.25, 20:38:21] ~â€¯Filippo: Thank you for the post, I have a question: I didnâ€™t understand if costs increase for importing in bulk or the fees you talk about were already active  in the past
[5.02.25, 20:44:39] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: So it depends on the shipment method youâ€™re doing in bulk. Like if youâ€™re doing DDP shipping with a freight company, they are just giving you a tracking number to UPS or Fedex. That form of pricing is duties + taxes and youâ€™re charged on a per KG basis. 

If youâ€™re importing in bulk the more legitimate way where youâ€™re working with a customs broker to handle your customs clearance, you will be paying the Duties (based on HTS code) + tariff that the HTS code falls under (tariff exempt, 7.5%, 15% or 25%) + the 10% additional tariff. Then there are two small percentage fees .125% (harbor maintenance) and .3464% (merchandise processing). These percentages are based on the value of your goods.
[5.02.25, 20:45:41] ~â€¯Filippo: It gets deep. But are these tariffs on bulk orders new ?
[5.02.25, 20:49:05] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: The only part that is new is the 10% that was announced and the removal of the $800 de minimus rule. The others percentages were always there. With de minimus being removed, now any kind of bulk shipment that gets valued under $800 will have these duties and tariffs in place. You just need to make sure you know the HTS codes of your product and youâ€™re selecting the right one. 

Your supplier in China will have an HS code, but youâ€™ll need to make sure on your side that the correct HTS code is being used. Sometimes there are products that can fall under 2 different HTS codes and its up to you which one you want to use. Of course its always better to use the HTS code that has lower duty amount (assuming you have the option to choose between two HTS codes).

[14.02.25, 14:59:10] ~â€¯Jonny: for those guys who are being ripped, here's what we did when it happened to us in the past (cant directly correlate but they stopped running our creatives after a week or so)

take your worst 3-5 creatives that are shit (KPIs wise), launch a campaign with them in for like $5 a day. Dupe them each 50-100 times. Then when competitors look on your ad library, they'll think these are top performers based on how many of the same creative is running.

[25.02.25, 21:31:47] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: Be careful inserting an EIN in lieu of an ITIN - particularly if this account isnâ€™t warmed up at all.  This can be ripe for a hold or shutdown if you get through and start to process on this. (People who havenâ€™t opted in through a pop-up letâ€™s say, will also receive the Abandoned Checkout email).

If you are looking for alternative to Klaviyo try:

Omnisend: Cheaper and very decent in terms of functionality.

Yotpo: Very close to Klaviyo in terms of features and you only pay for the amount of emails you send.

[14.03.25, 8:24:55] ~â€¯Simeon Petrov: One is not better than the other. They just track different activities on your website. Shopify doesnâ€™t have active on site and and viewed product metrics but they are automatically added by Klaviyo once you make the integration with it.

The only similar metric between API and Shopify is the Added-to-Cart, and the difference is that the Added-to-Cart API needs to be added by you manually in the back end while the other one is automatically added once you integrated Klaviyo with Shopify along with the other new custom events.

Although some say that Added-to-Cart Shopify also works when you add products using quick add in collection pages for some store. While added-to-cart API doesnâ€™t and only works in the product pages.
[14.03.25, 8:27:00] ~â€¯Bazeed: Perfect makes sense, thank you

[17.03.25, 19:18:17] ~â€¯Aman: Not wise to look at individual ads as having potential. The campaign works together to achieve an overall ROAS. [17.03.25, 19:18:53] ~â€¯Aman: Same applies to keeping a low amount of campaigns in the account so meta can optimise on an account level so that over all ROAS in the account is as efficient as possible.

But yeah, if you get a DMCA notice make sure you counter it. Is the only way to not make it count towards their 3 strike policy.

If you get 3 DMCAâ€™s they close your store

[19.03.25, 17:58:21] ~â€¯Simeon Petrov: Iâ€™ve watched 3 courses on pop-ups from pop-up tool creators so hereâ€™s the summary so you donâ€™t have to ğŸ˜„:

1. If you run cold traffic to funnel then donâ€™t show an email collection pop-up. More often than note it will decrease cvr. (Optional to show it with the condition being a deep scroll on the page like 70-80%

2. If you run cold traffic to product page on shopify, set the time delay of the pop-up to at least 25s-45s or exit intent only if you want to be on the safer side. (You can A/B test this and see how different time delays impact your cvr to determine what works for your brand)
3. â On Shopify homepage you can go more agressive with an 8s time delay. People there are not actively educating themselves about a specific product or making a purchasing descision on the spot.

To sum it up:

On funnels - no pop-up or deep scroll

On product/collections pages on shopify- longer time delays or exit intent only

On home page - 8-15s (wonâ€™t affect cvr)

[20.03.25, 11:49:17] ~â€¯Growg: So Here is quick Fundamentals 
To increase AOV by roughly 10-20% 

Consider following things
1. Test Bundle Funnel 
2. â Understand you unit economics and pricing, test what is the break price for your buyer i.e at which point fricition is there. 
Ex - If you are selling currently at $49, increase the price by a 1$ and simultaneously check at which point it breaks . 
3. Post purchase should be dynamic.

Most of the time you need to understand economics and than strategies it

[24.03.25, 21:27:32] ~â€¯OB: I run a US LLC but just came across an ad promoting Hong Kong company, does anyone have any insight about HK companies and how they compare to a US LLC for ecom?
[24.03.25, 21:37:47] ~â€¯Zsombor: You have a uae corp? Let's talk
[24.03.25, 21:42:55] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: Depends on where you are selling.  Makes sense to have US LLC if high percentage of sales are in the US.  If US LLC is used for a majority of sales outside of US, that is likely going to create stability issues with the US based processor.   You want to keep high percentage of sales in the US for processors in that region.  Over 40% of sales outside of US, then it gets expensive and lots of failed transactions, performance concerns, etc.

HK has been much more flexible for businesses selling into other regions such as EU, UK, AUS.  Particularly if newer set-up and just getting warmed up.

Ideally having an entity where a bulk of your sales is the best for maximum processor stability and access to local payment methods, currency and high authorization rates. â€<This message was edited>
[24.03.25, 21:43:32] ~â€¯Chris Rivera: I love this answer Mike.  I agree 100%
[24.03.25, 21:44:29] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: Thanks @â¨~Chris Riveraâ© ğŸ™‚
[24.03.25, 22:19:42] ~â€¯Muhammad Hamza: Which third party payment gateway is recommended if we don't have a US business bank account to attach with Shopify payments.

But I need better alternative especially which gives faster payouts with multiple currency acceptance option so the cash flow is not affected.
[24.03.25, 23:02:21] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: Depends where you are located and where you are selling.  2checkout is a merchant of record solution so they are good with providing local payments methods and currency conversion in most regions but rates are steeper than other MORâ€™s.  Plus stricter underwriting and support is a bit suspect since they were acquired by Verifone.  If you need some recs feel free to DM.  Lots of 3rd party alternatives, just depends on your overall GTM strategy, product, requirements, volumes etc.

[26.03.25, 22:21:51] ~â€¯Mark Wagner: Damn this is tough to hear - reached out to you directly on it. I own Disputifier and if you guys have any questions, please feel free to contact me directly. We've grown a shit ton over the past 6 months and are still building the teams / systems to catch up with the growth - regardless, no excuse for us no showing a demo. Just a few things you guys should keep in mind when exploring chargeback platforms: 

- How do they treat SAFE alerts? Most providers just add this in as a normal Ethoca alert and donâ€™t let you turn these off. The Majority of these SAFE alerts donâ€™t turn into a chargeback so youâ€™re left paying for and refunding customers that didnâ€™t charge back. Causes a ton of â€œfalse positivesâ€. We turn these off by default. 
- Do they flag/credit overlap? Are you ever paying for multiple different types of alerts on the same order? 
- Do they flag/credit canâ€™t find, already refunded alerts? Are you ever paying for alerts that doesnâ€™t prevent a chargeback?
- Do they offer PayPal alerts? We just launched this in beta, no one else offers it at the moment. 
- Do they offer Klarna alerts? Weâ€™re launching these next month. 
- Do they offer Order Insight / Compelling Evidence / Consumer Clarity? This will be even more important with the new visa dispute program 
- Do they also fight chargebacks not caught by alerts? Do they provide transaction scanning for fraud prevention? How about lost/late order identification for order not received prevention?

Weâ€™re not perfect by any stretch - but have the most complete chargeback platform in the market and itâ€™s only getting better. If you guys have questions or suggestions, Iâ€™m an open book

Great content + great performance = great ad

Average content + great performance = good ad

The first will always get more favor from Meta because Meta doesn't just reward ads that make sales, it rewards ads that people have a good time consuming

[4.04.25, 12:23:34] ~â€¯Mithiran: What do you normally put in the email flows? And what are the solutions you give when people complain?
[4.04.25, 12:23:37] ~â€¯Bazeed: Amazing thanks man
[4.04.25, 12:28:40] Carlos Leeseman: First email: Thank you for your order, our team is wrapping your order immediately
Second email: Your order has been shipped
Third email (halfway through shipping): Your order is on its way from our manufacturer to our warehouse
Fourth email: Your order has arrived at our local center
Fifth email: Your order is ready for delivery

â€”â€”

If people have paid for shipping, we refund them if shipping takes longer than what we say on our website. Furthermore, if they get really angry, or want to complain to the bank, we sometimes refund 20/30%. But 9/10x this is not even necessary if communication is good, clear and honest with the customer and especially if you call the customer. I really NEVER get disputes/issues with payment processors because of â€œlongâ€ shipping.

[9.04.25, 19:05:26] ~â€¯Bazeed: Anyone has a contact for inbound call center for u.s?
[9.04.25, 20:01:20] Greg Sourcing China Trybello: Hey Guys. Apologies for the long message and being a bit MIA in the group. The tariff stuff has been keeping us busy. Here are 10 things weâ€™ve been thinking about and sharing with our clients and we wanted to share it here too in case itâ€™s helpful.

1. No One Knows the "Final" Tariff Details Yet
Thereâ€™s still no clarity onÂ how high the new tariffs will beÂ â€” they could beÂ 104%, 129% (still unknown if section 301 is still in place as an FYI), or something else entirelyÂ â€” orÂ how broadly theyâ€™ll be appliedÂ (just China, or China plus other parts of Asia?). We also donâ€™t know which product categories will be affected or how implementation will roll out. We anticipate uncertainty to continue for the near-future.

2. While Tariff Numbers Are Unclear, Plan for De Minimis to Be Removed
Tariffs may still be TBD, butÂ de minimis removal is looking very likely.Â This means all shipments into the U.S. under $800 could now be taxed â€” a big hit to brands relying on direct-from-China fulfillment.Â And itâ€™s not just about cost:Â longer delivery times from ChinaÂ could lead to moreÂ refund requests, lower customer satisfaction, and fewer repeat purchasesÂ â€” all of which hurt your LTV and CAC efficiency.

3. Work Directly With Factories â€” Not Just Fulfillment Companies
Fulfillment partners help with logistics, but not your product costs.Â Good quality factories are very collaborative and will help you come up with ways to reduce your costs by purchasing certain raw materials or buying at certain volumes to help bring down your cost.Â From our experience, fulfillment and trade companies typically mark up prices by 30%-100+%

4. Consider Hybrid Fulfillment or Fulfillment from the U.S.
Consider taking a hybrid fulfillment model (fulfill from US and China-based warehouse based on location of the customer) or consider fulfilling directly from the US (bulk ship to US 3PL). Yes, tariffs still apply when importing in bulk â€” but there are ways to consolidate shipment to lower tariff/duty payment. There are 2 benefits - lower per unit fulfillment cost and faster delivery to the customer - which means fewer refund requests, which prevents your CAC from creeping up.Â 

5. Diversify Market (look beyond US)
Scaling intoÂ international marketsÂ (like the EU, UK, or Canada) can help offset U.S. margin compression. If youâ€™re currently U.S.-only, youâ€™re more exposed to changes in domestic logistics and trade policy.

6. Diversity Manufacturing (Where Numbers work out)
Diversifying doesnâ€™t mean ditching China â€” it means adding a second factory base (like theÂ U.S., Mexico, or Europe) for flexibility and regional fulfillment. This doesnâ€™t apply for every industry, but for some industries like skincare and supplements, this is very doable. This can significantly bring down your cost due to the tariffs. That said, this is NOT a guarantee b/c of the changing policies. Manufacturing costs in the US are increasing due to greater demand and their reliance on China for ingredients and machines.Â 
-If you're targeting Europe, Australia, etc. youâ€™ll need to still produce in China since the numbers make sense.Â 
-Anyone thats selling gadgets will still need to produce in China since the US is not set up properly, nor is it even cost effective to produce gadgets. If you sell apparel, you can explore working with other countries since theyâ€™re more competitive than China on price.Â 
(Weâ€™ve been working with a lot of skincare and supplements brands to set up U.S. production and making sure it makes sense economicallyâ€” you'll need to carefully compare total landed cost, not just per-unit price.)

7. Thereâ€™s No One-Size-Fits-All Strategy â€” You Need to carefully compare numbers
Every brand is different. What works for a $60 skincare serum wonâ€™t work for a $20 phone charger. A lot of what we've been doing with brands is to help them figure out steps 4-6 (fulfillment strategy, target market and manufacturing strategy) to optimize for cost and on-time fulfillment.Â  Make decisions based on your numbers â€” not someone elseâ€™s playbook.Â 

8. Review and Optimize Your HTS Codes to reduce cost
While the tariffs are applied across all product categories, they are not the same when it comes to duties. Sometimes an HTS code for a product falls under two HTS codes. One could be a common HTS code used for the exact product, but another could be used due to the products function. In some cases, like weâ€™ve seen in the past, the difference in duties can be in range of 6%. If youâ€™re importing large volumes of product into the US, the duties savings can be significant.Â 

9. Negotiate Better Payment Terms With Manufacturers
For those that have an established relationship with their manufacturer, try working on paying a 20% deposit for your order. Then paying 50% upon completion of production and paying the final 30% 30 days after delivery. If youâ€™re placing orders valued at $300k, for instance, thatâ€™s $90k of money freed up for a month that you can put into marketing and scaling up your business.Â 

10. Smaller Dropshipping Brands Are Most at Risk; opportunity for medium-large brands.
Smaller businesses, especially pure dropshipping businesses (that are not focused on building a brand and scaling) are most likely going to die out with the de minimus removal. They'll have to pivot to selling in other markets, such as the EU, UK, Canada and Austrailia. This is a tough period for everyone, but could allow 8-9 figure brands to gain more market share in the US in the long term. This of course hinges on them having good control over cashflow and production cost.Â 

Hope this is helpful and stay strong everyone. Hit me up if I can be helpful with anything. Iâ€™m also going to be doing a live call with @â¨Alex  Fedotoffâ© tomorrow to talk about this stuff.

[1.05.25, 9:40:28] ~â€¯Anatoly: Thought Iâ€™d drop an update in case someone finds it useful:

1. Thanks to everyone who DMd me personally with some help or advise, you guys are legends.
2. â I found out the breach happened through GoLogin proxy browser. Apparently their insider has been selling clients cookie data, making the access to profiles and ad accounts possible without passwords or 2FA. If you are using it, then stop and switch to something else immediately. After switching, change all your passwords and 2FA. Do not change it before you are on the new browser. Also see recent TP reviews backing this up. I am now back to using Incogniton, as many recommended.
3. â Despite trying to find Meta insiders or some sketchy options to get my account and money back, I got help from the least expected place and this is - Meta standard support. Not sure if they upped their game or I just was lucky, but after reporting the incident, they even called me to discuss it on the phone. As a result, I have got a full refund, outstanding debt written off and my account is back and running. 

The moral of the story, do not disregard Meta support. Although they are shit most of the time, you might just get lucky every now and then.

[8.05.25, 14:37:33] ~â€¯Simeon Petrov: Collect only emails for prospects with 1 offer (10% OFF). Then have the Phone number collection on a different pop-up that is showed only in front of existing email subscribers with a better offer (15% OFF). This was you also facilitate repeat purchases via your phone number collection pop-up.
[8.05.25, 14:38:21] ~â€¯Jonny: we offer 15% off for sms or email, our back end email numbers are very solid around 40%. working on improving margins so considering dropping opt in to 10%
[8.05.25, 14:39:01] ~â€¯Simeon Petrov: Depends on your margins. Typically 5-10% for email and then 15% OFF for phone number collection where your phone number collection is on a different pop-up as I mentioned in the message above.
[8.05.25, 14:40:02] ~â€¯Simeon Petrov: Trying to collect email and sms on same pop-up with 1 offer really decreases opt-in rates, subscription to conversion rates and causes friction. Even if you had the ability to offer people to skip the sms step if they didn't want to give their phone number, you'd still see lower opt-in rates in total.

[20.05.25, 13:35:12] ~â€¯Mikael: Anyone who can help with this? We just opened a new UK company and activated shopify payments. Now they are asking us for this? Anyone know a solution for this?
(We operate dropshipping from outside UK and our owner is not UK and does not live in UK)


Can you please describe what kind of business operations you currently have in the UK? 

Shopify has to follow regulatory and contractual obligations which require that we only provide financial services to merchants who are physically located in a supported region. Shopifyâ€™s standards for this requirement mean that registering your business in the region and obtaining a bank account is not enough.

To be eligible for Shopify Payments, you must meet one of the following criteria:

If you are a Sole Proprietor, the business owner must personally live in the country.
If you are a Company, LLC, or similar business type, you must be registered with the government of that country, and also be able to provide evidence of substantial operations physically happening there.

If you believe your business meets these requirements, please reply here with a detailed description of your operations in the UK.

Some examples of operational presence could include (but are not limited to): You rent or own warehouse space and ship your orders from there, you have an office there with employees consistently occupying the space, or you have a retail location(s) there. You may have other examples of operations you have in the country which youâ€™d like to provide: If you can respond with as much detail as possible, that is helpful for our review.

If you operate the business entirely from outside of the UK, you can confirm this also.

[24.05.25, 15:29:14] ~â€¯Davide: For those who are currently training, or have trained someone from video editing to a creative strategy role, what was your process like?
Because Iâ€™m considering guiding and teaching my video editor (he already understand ads, performance hooks, formats, and styles) toward becoming a strong copywriter.
From there, the final step would be evolving him into a creative strategist.
What are your thoughts on this path? Has anyone here taken a similar approach?
I know is a long and difficult process and maybe not the best and convenient process in terms of effort and time
[24.05.25, 15:49:56] ~â€¯UHO: Seen it wrk a few times. U start by pulling him into brainstorms, debriefs, and strategy convos, just to listen and absorb. Then have him write copy for his own edits, tweak scripts, test headlines. Give feedback fast, focus on why something works.

Next step, let him handle small briefs. Stuff like a mini product rollout or a single concept ad. Let him pick the hook, write the copy, suggest the format. Review with him, refine together.

Once thatâ€™s working, shift to building from scratch. Give him a product insight or audience pain point, ask him to frame the message, suggest content angles, back it up. Make him present it, strategyâ€™s as much about selling the idea as shaping it.

Itâ€™s not the fastest path. But if heâ€™s sharp and curious and loves his job, itâ€™s way more valuable than hiring someone. Youâ€™re building someone who gets your audience, your tone, and how to bridge ideas with execution. Time-heavy, but pays off long term.
[24.05.25, 16:41:49] ~â€¯Davide: Like you approach, I would just say that before giving him any pice of copy to write, I would like to teach REALLY well about the Foundations of copywriting. 
See himself if that copy is good or not, and why. 
Teach him about problem-agitate-solution, AIDA (attention, interest, desire and action) all the basic stuff about copywriting and advertising, authority, failed solutions, mechanism of the problemâ€¦ 

Then once he learned those, he can move on and starting experimenting what he learned, also because we donâ€™t have much time to explain everything, so courses, books, YouTube ecc ecc can be great o for him to speed the process himself.
[24.05.25, 17:01:19] ~â€¯Anatoly: Seems like a lot of work without necessarily any guarantee of success. Why not hire a solid ready creative strategist instead? Just curious
[24.05.25, 18:19:51] ~â€¯Davide: Thatâ€™s a option sure, it depends of how much cash you have to invest on, the brand size etc etc

[5.06.25, 8:45:04] Topi: If creatives were the #1 needle mover, from my experience should not stop doing them or at least closely monitoring the numbers even if you onboard agency

Often agencies cannot really create anything new, they just can scale what was already working

Outsourcing the #1 needle mover activity completely is not very good idea, at least before theyve proven to scale your ads week over week. Just wanted to point that out.

Cro for one product is like 3 hours per week work so you should anway run that no matter agencies or not

Other opportunities, itâ€™s hard for anyone give you advice without exactly know what youre doing, because its mostly situational.

But what i like to do is list down all my growth opportunities on comparison table and look for opportunities that can have big impact with low effort, or in other words things that you can test fast and there is no big downside if it didnâ€™t hit

[10.07.25, 16:40:48] ~â€¯Dawid: Does anyone here have a ai agency or knows someone , I have few questions
[10.07.25, 16:49:25] ~â€¯Zainab: Based on your win rate, hereâ€™s how you calculate how many tests you need to hit your goal:

For example, if your win rate is 20% and your target ad spend on Facebook is $300K, and your average spend per winning ad is $10K, then:
	â€¢	$300K / $10K = 30 winners needed
	â€¢	With a 20% win rate, you need 5 tests to get 1 winner
	â€¢	So, to get 30 winners: 30 Ã— 5 = 150 tests

In short:
You need to test 150 ads to hit 30 winners, which allows you to deploy your full $300K budget.

[11.07.25, 5:14:13] ~â€¯Manoj Bashyal: Try to implement the following elements:

1. Add trust badges near Add to Cart and checkout like SSL, secure payment, Money Back Guarantee etc.
2. Social proof pop-ups like â€œX just bought thisâ€ to build urgency and trust
3. Use a dedicated cart page with clear USPs (Free shipping, Easy returns, Product Guarantees etc.)
4. Add a checkout banner like 100% Secure, Free Shipping to reassure visitors 
5. Show final total early, no hidden fees. 
6. Enable Buy Now, Pay Later with Shop Pay, Klarna, etc.

manofy.com/cro

[14.07.25, 12:03:27] ~â€¯Matt: Quick win update for those who are doing CBO campaigns; split by static and video, weâ€™ve seen much better results (20% reduction in CAC) by doing this as often statics would lose spend to more engaging videos if all in 1 campaign. [21.07.25, 8:55:20] ~â€¯Yente Dhooge: How do you think about this for other positions like Creative strategist, video editor, ... ?
[21.07.25, 9:06:40] ~â€¯Steve: Video Editors can be tested, because they're easy to find.

Strategists depends. I feel different people consider creative strategist different things.

I've always thought of that role as a creative director - overseeing everything from VSLs to pages to branding etc and how it all comes together. In this regard, that's someone I want to spend time making sure is the right person that is on the team for a long time.

But I realize a lot of people view that strategist role differently. So I wouldn't really be looking to "test" them as much as I would have a 60 day window in which, if they're not performing or are not a fit, I'd fire them fast
[21.07.25, 9:07:01] ~â€¯Steve: Hire slow, fire fast - continues to be a good strategy time and time again

Then go to inspect the elements you like, upsells, quiz funnels, bundles often have some indicator of itâ€™s backend. If not, you can likely conclude itâ€™s custom built.
Aside from that, view page source (next to inspect) will sometimes also tell you stuff (use cmd f)

[31.07.25, 20:16:06] ~â€¯Davide: from an email of alex cooper:

The 4 Elements of Every Great Prompt
Here are the 4 core elements that I try to work into the majority of my prompts:
Identity + Task + Context + Output
Identity
This is about telling the AI who it should be.
E.g. â€œYou are a seasoned direct response copywriter trained to extract winning Facebook ad headlines directly from customer reviews. You write like the best performance marketers in the world â€” people like David Ogilvy, Dave Gerhardt, and Harmon Brothers.â€
Task
Clearly define exactly what you want the model to do.
E.g. â€œYour job is to analyze the customer reviews I provide and select the ones that are most suitable for static Facebook ad headlines. Then, rank these review snippets by how confident you are that each could work as a headline for a prospect who has never heard of our brand. Prioritize relevance, specificity, and emotional clarity over generic praise or brand loyalty.â€
Context
Give the AI both good and bad examples, and explain WHY they're good or bad (this is arguably the most important part).
E.g. â€œA good example:
â€œThe only shampoo that ended my dandruff battleâ€
â€” Clear pain point, outcome-driven, universally relatable
A bad example:
â€œIâ€™m super picky, and these guys hit it out of the park from A to Z.â€
â€” Too vague, not specific to any particular pain point or audienceâ€
Output Structure
Tell the AI EXACTLY how you want the response formatted for a more accurate output:
E.g. â€œA ranked list of 5â€“10 customer quotes (best to worst), with each quote labeled A, B, C, etc.
Under each quote, add a short justification: explain why this one is strong/weak for cold audiences.
Then, group them into tiers:
Tier 1 = Highly usable as-is
Tier 2 = Might need light editing
Tier 3 = Too vagueâ€
So altogether, once weâ€™ve added a little more meat to this prompt hereâ€™s what it looks like:

Hereâ€™s a prompt I made using the 4- element prompt structure
A few prompting hacksâ€¦
Here are some other lines I like to add to my prompts to help me improve the outputs:
Rate each output from 1-10 and only show me 8+ quality
Once youâ€™re happy with your final output, ask "What would I have had to ask to get this exact output?" (reverse engineer your wins)
For each output, tell it that it was a 4/10, and you need a 10/10 - impress me
Raise the stakes by adding "if this does not [INSERT GOAL], I will get fired. It is that important"
Ask â€œNow rewrite this as if it's version 10 after 9 rounds of expert feedbackâ€
At the end of your initial prompt, add in this sentence: â€œBefore you give your response, what questions do you have that would help you give a better response?â€
For each output, ask, â€œHow could you improve that?â€ Keep asking this question over and over
Tell it to act as an expert. E.g. "Act as a world class direct response copywriter" or "write like you're being paid $1,000,000 to do this"
Raising the stakes has been proven to improve the outputs that AI gives you. Hence why I end up using these all the time haha.
Build Your Prompt Library
And finally, once you have started making prompts like this, youâ€™ll want to share them across your team.
Building a prompt library is something Iâ€™d recommend every creative team out there does today.
It just saves so much time in people not rebuilding prompts that have already been built.

[15.08.25, 12:45:08] ~â€¯Vaidik Ruparel: i do have a system that somewhat resonates with what youâ€™re asking for itâ€™s a 

Ad Creatives Testing Framework
[15.08.25, 12:45:09] ~â€¯Vaidik Ruparel: a bit of a long message but here it is:
[15.08.25, 12:48:03] ~â€¯Vaidik Ruparel: *Creative Testing Framework (Ad Matrix Method)*

*Step 1*: Set Up a Google Sheet Matrix

*Top Row (X-Axis):*
List all your customer avatars (target audiences).
Example: Keto, Vegan, Parents, etc.

*Left Column (Y-Axis):*
List all your ad types.
Examples:

- UGC Video

- Feature Callout

- Testimonial (Static or Video)

- Founder Story

- Problem/Solution etc.

*Cells (Intersection):*
In each cell, write out pain points or desires relevant to that avatar and match them with an ad type â€” each one represents a new angle to test.

*Step 2: Testing Phases*

*Phase 1 â€“ Angle Testing (Within One Avatar)*

- Pick one winning ad type that historically performs well (e.g., UGC Video).

- Use it to test multiple angles (pain points/desires) for a single avatar.

Example: Test 10 angles â†’ Identify top 3 performers.

*Phase 2 â€“ Format Expansion*

- Take the top 3 performing angles from Phase 1.

- Now test these angles across all your top-performing ad types.

- Find combinations of winning angles + winning ad types.

*Final Goal:*

Identify the best-performing avatar, angle, and ad type combination.

Once you find these winners, you scale and repeat.
[15.08.25, 12:51:24] ~â€¯Vaidik Ruparel: this creative planner ensures i dont miss out on any marketing angles and lays out things very clearly for my editor. might be helpful for everyone here :) â€<This message was edited>

â€[15.08.25, 18:37:19] ~â€¯Ben Mansour: â€image omitted
[15.08.25, 18:38:53] ~â€¯Ben Mansour: in asana you structure like this, you create a task with the script idea, you put it in draft, when the script is ready you attach the doc to the task and move the task to ready, the editor takes it from there, when he finished teh first version of the creative, he attaches a frame.io link and moves the task to draft complete
[15.08.25, 18:39:33] ~â€¯Ben Mansour: then you or the creative strategist, reviews the creative, put your comments on frame if there is any, then move it to edits needed or launch
[15.08.25, 18:40:12] ~â€¯Ben Mansour: no need to communicate a lot with them like this, everybody has access to asana and they know their jobs
[15.08.25, 18:40:47] ~â€¯Ben Mansour: for the content the editor usually gathers stock footage we need, idk how often they do it
[15.08.25, 22:57:20] ~â€¯Yusuf: We do it exactly the same just with clickup though.

Clickup Board with different stages (scripting, content, cutting, review, launch,..)

And then in the task description we put the hook idea, body script with comments and also the raw footage/voiceovers.
[15.08.25, 22:58:00] ~â€¯Yusuf: And after they're done they upload it to the task and we do a feedback loop with frame.io if it's not perfect yet
â€[15.08.25, 23:19:27] ~â€¯Guy Edan: â€image omitted

[16.08.25, 0:06:14] ~â€¯Steve: - Scroll stoppers
- actor to do the script
- female actor to do the script
- new captions
- new caption style
- split screen the ad, run a sale banner on the right hand side
- add an AI avatar pointing up to the ad
- split screen the ad top to bottom, show someone on bottom watching the ad on their phone reacting to the ad
- take beat performing hooks and stack them together at the start â€<This message was edited>
[16.08.25, 0:06:23] ~â€¯Steve: Endless amount. We do several of these pretty regularly
[16.08.25, 0:07:23] Topi: Divide by soft iterations VS heavy iterations

Soft iterations are fast and easy such as headline iterations, scroll stopper iterations, changing video speed etc 

Heavy iterations are testing new leads or closes or recreating winning leads or body with new footage, changing actor

Thereâ€™s at least 20 ways to iterate on VSL.

Start from soft iterations and see what happens

Later move into heavier

In the beginning you most likely find lots of winners with soft and later its harder

Just make sure you donâ€™t burn your scaling profits into endless testing, quality over quantity, test budget max 20% of scaling budgets
[16.08.25, 0:08:09] Topi: Also stay organized so that you know what youâ€™ve tested and what worked, what not, over time you see patterns and become more effective
[16.08.25, 0:10:21] ~â€¯Mo: Cristal clear, Thanks bro
[16.08.25, 0:11:33] ~â€¯Mo: Straight to the point thanks man !ğŸ™ğŸ½
How do u stay organized & make sure u not testing what uve already tested. Do u have a structure/systems for this ?
[16.08.25, 0:14:07] Topi: Just make a â€œscript master sheetâ€ where you always list all your scripts

Mark down winners / losers 

After winners, just have columns of iteration performed yes / now + result

Something like that, over time you can make it more complex and more tailored to your needs. Most important is just to get started being organized
[16.08.25, 0:14:55] ~â€¯Steve: Find the iterations that seem to work well for you. Turn it into an SOP, then train video editors to do it automatically. We call it "winner treatment" and for most of those the editors can handle it themselves. Saves bandwith
[16.08.25, 7:22:54] ~â€¯Pramesh: yo bro, can you intro me to this please?

[19.08.25, 22:05:55] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: Wouldnâ€™t recommend this.  Have kept a close eye on these services for last few years and lots are scams or super high risk for the users.   Plus very expensive.  If used, it needs to be super controlled or 1 to 1 MID / entity set-up.

Or you can leverage a merchant of record provider. â€<This message was edited>

[30.08.25, 4:00:53] ~â€¯Mike Kasdorf: I had this with one brand. I introduced subscriptions, then suddenly had everyone buying the subscription price, then automatically asking to cancel. Given the volume I figured it was ppl gaming the system, so I added a stated policy that subscribers had to purchase at least 3 times before cancelling or they'd have to make up the difference to full price to cancel early. I've had a lot fewer "accidental" subscribers since then, and everyone else who has cancelled early has paid back the difference, no questions asked.

[18.09.25, 12:28:34] Carlos Leeseman: Hey guys, what strategy are you currently running on Meta right now?

Weâ€™ve been using an ABO creative testing campaign combined with a CBO scaling campaign for years already. Like any setup, it has its pros and cons. What we like about it is that every concept gets a fair shot since each ad set has its own daily budget. The downside, of course, is that weâ€™re â€œwastingâ€ some budget on non-winners, whereas with a single CBO campaign, Facebook often figures that out faster.

At the moment, weâ€™re pushing out 15â€“20 new concepts per week (which equals 15-20 new ad sets, with 3 variants inside each ad set).

Iâ€™m curious if there are any of you testing and scaling with a single CBO campaign? If so, how do you handle that with the same (or even higher) creative output? Weâ€™re testing this approach since last week, launched 19 new concepts into one CBO, and 90% of the budget ended up going almost entirely to one ad set, which means 1 concept out of the 19 weâ€™ve launched, what is incredible for me. Some people say that just means the others werenâ€™t winners, but my concern is that we might be missing out on potential winners with this structure.

What are you guys doing?

[25.09.25, 14:03:13] ~â€¯Steve: Just a courtesy reminder, as you already know, your ITIN application was filed to/received by the IRS on May 12th, 2025 and therefore is part of the 2nd week of May 2025 batch of ITIN applications at the IRS ITIN Department.

The IRS has advised us that we are not authorized to provide an exact time frame for how long this will take. The reason they have stated this to us is simply because the IRS ITIN Department is working to catch up on their backlog caused from the past holiday season and current US tax season. As a result they can not determine when they will be caught up on their backlog but rather provide updates on their progress and what batch of applications they have completed and what batches of ITIN applications they are currently working on.

The latest update we have received from the IRS in regards to your case and general ITIN Application processing:

-The IRS has finished processing all ITIN applications up to May 2025.

 -Please note some Tax Examiners may be behind or further along in the same month or some may already be working on the following month. Processing speeds vary per Tax Examiner based on caseload size, case types, supplemental information/documentation requests if applicable, etc.

-The IRS Tax Examiner assigned to your case is currently working on finishing their 1st, 2nd and 3rd week of May 2025 batch of applications in their caseload.

[5.10.25, 11:00:29] ~â€¯Mo: yes thats my case
[5.10.25, 11:05:33] ~â€¯Alvaro De Prada: Then this is exactly what I do:

Get 3/4 bills from agent where you have a ton of orders and divide them by country. 

Get the average shipping cost of each country and get the countries where you have 60-70% of the shipments. Comprare full 3/4 bills to last bill to see if your costs are going up or down or staying the same.

For those countries, on TW put shipping price as AVG + X$ (what you are comfortable with, I put 7). For the other countries, put AVG +1

Pick and pack depends on your set up, I pay flat fee no mater what so 1.5. If you pay by product, then get an AVG of entire bill and add 30/40% 

Cogs: exact cost

[30.10.25, 19:52:11] ~â€¯Alexander Lundberg: Sorry for the delay - hereâ€™s a guide

The tools I use are ChatGPT, Midjourney, and Nano Banana.
The key to getting consistent, high-quality images is to first build a moodboard that defines the vibe you want. Start by collecting reference images - either your own or from Pinterest - that match your desired look.

Once thatâ€™s done, upload them to Midjourney and create a moodboard.

Next, I go into ChatGPT with a sample image I like and ask it to write a JSON prompt describing the setting, angle, lighting, and product placement in the photo. The trick here is to let Midjourney generate a placeholder object for the product. I also make small adjustments if I want extra details.

Then I take this prompt into Midjourney, making sure itâ€™s generated using the moodboard I created.
I let Midjourney generate images until I find one I like - if the moodboard is good, itâ€™s usually spot on.

Finally, I bring the image into Nano Banana. I upload the Midjourney image with the placeholder, then attach a second image of my product (must have a transparent background). I use a prompt like: â€œReplace the object in the first picture with the exact object from the second.â€

Finally, I take the finished image from Nano Banana into Photoshop to remove the watermark and add any text or final touches.

Iâ€™ve got an old friend who runs an agency specializing in this - Iâ€™m sure heâ€™d love to take some of you on!

Wishing you all the best of luck for Q4! - If you need any help my DMs are open.

It is as well a judgment on how much you area ok to scale and decrease your ROAS to get more volume 

Doing ROAS 2 at 2k spend per day is probably better than 600 at 3 ROAS in terms of MONEY

[25.11.25, 0:06:38] ~â€¯Cocow: Great question ğŸ¤£

Break down and identify the best winning ads that are really crushing on the listicle. Relaunch these same ads again on the listicle url so that they start acquire some data and then, you can optimize time by time your listicle and still run your pdp 

Then you have two pages for different purposes. If at the moment the listicle is crushing it and you want to keep the momentum , you can relaunch your test and out 99% traffic on your listicle if you want to continue on these good results. Then once your new launches are doing better on the new url on meta slightly transition your new launches on the listicle for specific ads CONGRUANT to your listicle 

Then you keep your pdp for statics , mof and bof ads and the listicle for more TOF (assuming here your listicle is TOF ğŸ˜…)

[11.12.25, 6:39:36] ~â€¯Roland: I am starting a new meta account for a client, he already has - im not kidding - around 400 concepts with variations each, around 1200 ads in total. Mix of statics and videos.

- â Launch into CBO, 1 concept with all its variations per ad set

[11.12.25, 7:23:09] ~â€¯Ezra Liran: Bro does anyone have an actual consistent way to take people down who are ripping your brand 1 to 1? Bustem is so ass and all these softwares are super trash. So frustrating ngl.
[11.12.25, 7:35:04] ~â€¯Al: Option A: I'd probably start with ~20 concepts only and here's what I'd do:

- focus 70-80% on subjectively the best stage 3 concepts (solution aware/product unaware) with wide creative diversity
- have 1-2 of the best concepts max on the bottom stages (sales image ads/comparison ads)
- the rest on great and varied stg1/stg2 concepts (problem unaware // problem aware/solution unaware)

I would run ASC with 1 adset per concept and $20 minimum spend per adset ($400 locked, $600 free). Let them run for at least 5 days before starting to turn shit off.

Once a week, launch another 2-5 concepts as you turn 2-5 off.

Option B: ASC adsets work better with creative diversity inside directly, and flexible ads are working well for us. If you already know what works from other channels and are not as concerned about which specific variation of each concept worked best, you could:

- Create 1 adset for each stage of awareness (stg1-5)
- Dump ~20 flexible ads in each (total ~100 ads) - each with one concept and it's variations
- Give adsets for Stages 1-4 a low minimum spend like $50, so the campaign still has plenty of room to optimize spend as it sees fit
- Give Stage 5 a max spend (I'd suggest ~20% of budget to start with so it doesn't spend it all uselessly on BOF)
- Let it run for at least 5 days (ideally 1-2 weeks) and start turning off ads that spend but underperform. Don't touch ads that don't spend. Add new ones as you turn these off

I'd go with Option A if you weren't sure what angles/personas/hooks etc work yet, so slowly you can analyze each concept variation's performance.

I'd go with B if you somewhat knew and just wanted to lean more into Meta's optimization
[11.12.25, 7:35:45] ~â€¯Al: Option A is our BAU and how we grew to 8figs basically. Option B is what we're currently testing against A and is performing better, BUT the ads are already heavily optimized and we know what works
[11.12.25, 7:38:17] ~â€¯Al: You say Keto so I suggest more Stg3 because at 4M there's still a lot of market to capture that already knows about keto (I.e. I know I have a problem and I know keto could solve it but idk your brand).

[31.12.25, 20:12:40] ~â€¯Giovanni: And Iâ€™m selling in Europe right now with no problems with card declines but as far as I know it happens with the US
[31.12.25, 20:33:11] ~â€¯Mike Ramsey: You will have higher decline rates on any cross border transaction unless you process through a merchant of record or you establish an entity in that region. 

These sales may flag as fraud at a US cardholderâ€™s bank if they interact / purchase with a foreign entity such as HK.   Itâ€™s a false decline in most cases even though the transaction is legit.

If you have established / proven sales in the US, probably worth it to look at setting up an entity there and then routing transactions through the US entity vs. HK.  Youâ€™ll see an almost instant uplift in approvals (>10% in most cases)

[2.01.26, 1:57:24] ~â€¯Value Adding Personality: I would not fire him outright. I would get on a call, have an honest conversation, and understand what is really going on. If needed, issue a clear warning and expectations. I have seen situations like this before. In one case, a call revealed the person was grieving the loss of a parent. We gave him time off, and he returned stronger and more committed. In another case, performance dropped because founders had created bottlenecks. Every decision required their approval, approvals took forever, and yet results were still expected. Motivation died, not talent.

Be human first. Termination should be the last option, not the first reaction. Give people time and a fair chance to improve. Many of you have bad ads running right now, yet you do not â€œfireâ€ Meta. You analyze what went wrong, adjust, and allow room for optimization. Treat people with the same patience and logic, thank me later.

We recently learned of a disruption within our system. Upon discovery, we immediately began working with our IT staff and third-party forensic specialists to commence a thorough investigation of the nature and scope of this incident. If you were impacted, we highly recommend that you contact Shopify Payments or your payment processor to stop any refunds that were processed. It is important that you do this as soon as possible.
